strategic_profile.executive_summary: The University of Kentucky is a public land-grant research university in Lexington, Kentucky. Founded in 1865 by John Bryan Bowman as the Agricultural and Mechanical College of Kentucky, the university is one of the state's two land-grant institutions.
strategic_profile.market_position: Strong regional presence with growing national recognition in health sciences and engineering.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Seeks a diverse class of students with strong academic potential, demonstrated leadership, and a commitment to community engagement. Holistic review process considers grades, test scores, essays, and extracurriculars.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Strategic focus on health sciences will continue to drive research funding.
Alumni network is highly engaged, particularly in Kentucky and surrounding states.
Opportunities exist to further leverage athletic success for broader institutional branding.
Investment in student success initiatives is crucial for retention.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Vibrant campus life with strong emphasis on athletics (especially basketball), numerous student organizations, and a friendly, Southern hospitality atmosphere.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Campus is walkable, but a comprehensive bus system (Cat Cab) serves off-campus housing and remote parking. Traffic can be heavy around major events.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Significant contributions in medical research, agricultural sciences, advanced manufacturing, and Appalachian studies. A Carnegie R1 institution with a growing research portfolio.

current_status.test_policy_details: The University of Kentucky is test-optional for admission through the 2028-29 academic year for most freshman applicants and transfer applicants with fewer than 24 credit hours. Students are not required to submit ACT or SAT scores. However, submitting scores is optional and can strengthen an application, especially if the GPA is lower. Submitted test scores must be official and are considered as part of a holistic review process. The university evaluates applicants without test scores by reviewing the rigor of high school coursework, extracurricular activities, and a written essay.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Data for Class of 2029 (entering Fall 2025) is preliminary or not yet fully released. Acceptance rate is based on 2025 admission cycle projections/early data.
Enrollment data (enrolled_total) for this class was not readily available from external sources citing the Common Data Set.

gpa.notes: The University of Kentucky reports an average weighted GPA of 3.675 for admitted undergraduates, with the 25th percentile at 3.2 and the 75th percentile at 4.0. For unweighted GPAs, the average is 3.375, with the 25th percentile at 3.0 and the 75th percentile at 3.75. High school grades are considered a very important part of a student's application. The University of Kentucky employs a holistic review process, considering the entirety of the application. Approximately 39% of admitted students had a GPA of 3.75 or higher, and 10.2% had a 4.0 GPA. Regarding high school class rank, 29% were in the top tenth, 56% in the top quarter, and 85% in the top half.

testing.Policy Note: Test-optional through the 2028-29 academic year. Self-reporting of scores is allowed, and the university considers the highest composite score or highest combined scores from multiple test dates for the SAT and the ACT composite score.

men.note: Data for the 2025-2026 admissions cycle, for the Class of 2026.

women.note: Data for the 2025-2026 admissions cycle, for the Class of 2026.

colleges.name: Martin-Gatton College of Agriculture, Food and Environment

majors.name: Human Nutrition
prerequisite_courses: CHE 170 General Chemistry I
CHE 175 General Chemistry I Lab
CHE 180 General Chemistry II
CHE 185 General Chemistry II Lab
BIO 148 General Biology I OR BIO 152 General Biology II OR BIO 208 Principles of Biology II
DHN 212 Introduction to Human Nutrition
DHN 241 Applied Nutrition
majors.notes: Students start as a pre-major and require a 2.8 GPA in specific chemistry, biology, and nutrition courses for upper-division admission. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Forestry
majors.special_requirements: Experiential learning requirement (HRT 395 Special Problem or HRT 399 Internship).
majors.notes: Professional degree program, accredited by the Society of American Foresters. Small classes with hands-on outdoor training. Spring Field Semester involves travel and work at UK's Robinson Forest. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: The Martin-Gatton CAFE Agriculture Community is a Living Learning Program, likely housed within one of the general residence halls that supports LLPs. While a specific hall isn't detailed, LLP housing generally offers shared living spaces and specialized programming. [2]
colleges.student_archetype: First-semester freshmen with interests in agriculture, food (from cultivation to digestion), and environmental topics (from sustainability to natural resources). [2]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Incoming freshmen with a strong interest in agricultural sciences, food systems, or environmental studies who want to engage with peers and faculty sharing similar passions should consider joining this community. [2]

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences

majors.name: Biology
notable_professors: Dr. Carol Baskin (Professor)
Dr. Robin Cooper (Professor)
Dr. Elizabeth Duncan (Associate Professor)
Dr. Ann C. Morris (Professor and Chair, Retinal Development and Regeneration)
Dr. David Westneat (Professor and Director, Ecological Research and Education Center)
majors.notes: General undergraduate admission requires unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 or higher. UK is test-optional through 2028-29. Median early career earnings for Biology majors are approximately $21,456. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

core_courses: UK Core Arts and Creativity Course
electives: Creative Writing Workshops (fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction)
Courses in 20th Century British and Irish Literature

notable_professors: Dr. Jonathan Allison (Professor, Twentieth-Century British and Irish Literature)
Dr. Matthew Giancarlo (Professor, Medieval English literature)
Dr. Pearl James (Associate Professor, War in literature, film, visual art, and propaganda)

Median early career earnings for English language and literature graduates are approximately $23,244. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Psychology

core_courses: PSY 215 Introduction to Psychology as a Science

notable_professors: Dr. Chana K. Akins (Professor, Substance Use Research)
Dr. Christia Spears Brown (Associate Dean for Student Engagement and Success, Developmental and Social Psychology)
Dr. Jessica Burris (Professor, Cancer Survivorship and Smoking Cessation)
Dr. Rachel H. Farr (Professor, Developmental Psychology, LGBTQ families)
Dr. Jonathan Golding (Professor, Psychology and the Law)

Dr. Michelle Martel (Department Chair, Developmental Psychopathology, ADHD)
majors.notes: General undergraduate admission requires unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 or higher. UK is test-optional through 2028-29. Median early career earnings for Psychology graduates are approximately $24,569. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: Students typically reside in general university residence halls, which offer options like four-person suites, two-bedroom suites, and for upperclassmen, two-bedroom or four-bedroom apartments. These halls provide standard amenities such as study areas, kitchens, laundry, and recreational spaces. [4, 29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: A broad range of undergraduate students pursuing diverse academic interests within the liberal arts and sciences. They are often engaged in a wide variety of campus organizations and activities. [15]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students interested in a comprehensive university experience with a wide array of academic and extracurricular opportunities will find a suitable environment. Those seeking a traditional dorm experience with the flexibility to engage across many disciplines will thrive. [15]

colleges.name: Gatton College of Business and Economics

majors.name: Accounting
prerequisite_courses: Admission to UK as 'Pre-Accounting' major. Specific pre-major requirements (viewable in Academic Catalog) for full admission to the program.
majors.notes: Students apply and enter this program as 'Pre-Accounting' majors. Full admission occurs after completing pre-major requirements. Program accredited by AACSB International. Total 120 credit hours required for BSA. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Finance
prerequisite_courses: Admission to UK as 'Pre-Finance' major. Specific pre-major requirements (viewable in Academic Catalog) for full admission to the program.
notable_professors: Dr. Taylor Begley (Gatton College AI Fellow, Financial Intermediation, Regulation, Mortgage Markets)
Dr. Chris Clifford (Department Chair, DuPont Endowed Chair in Banking and Financial Services)
Dr. Igor Cunha (Director of MS Finance Program, Corporate Finance, Financial Economics)
Dr. Will Gerken (Real Estate Endowed Professor of Finance, Financial Advisor Misconduct)
Dr. Kristine Hankins (William E. Seale Endowed Chair in Business, Corporate Finance, Risk Management)
Dr. Russell Jame (Ashland Oil Professorship, Investment Research, Democratization of Investing)
Dr. David Sovich (Philip Morris Associate Professor of Finance, Empirical Household and Corporate Finance)
majors.notes: Students apply and enter this program as 'Pre-Finance' majors. Full admission occurs after completing pre-major requirements. Program accredited by AACSB International. Median early career earnings for Finance majors are approximately $45,000 - $50,000 (implied from general business earnings). Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Marketing
prerequisite_courses: Admission to UK as 'Pre-Marketing' major. Specific pre-major requirements (viewable in Academic Catalog) for full admission to the program.
notable_professors: Dr. David Hardesty (Carol Martin Gatton Endowed Chair of Marketing, Pricing, Emotional Intelligence, Consumer Behavior)
Dr. Allan Chen (Former Professor and Gatton Endowed Chair in Marketing, Research in Digital and Social Media Marketing)
majors.notes: Students apply and enter this program as 'Pre-Marketing' majors. Full admission occurs after completing pre-major requirements. Program accredited by AACSB International. Median early career earnings for Marketing majors are approximately $41,000 - $46,000 (implied from general business earnings). Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: Students generally utilize standard university residence halls or off-campus housing. The Gatton College building itself provides state-of-the-art classrooms, a finance learning facility, and collaborative study spaces. [32]
colleges.student_archetype: Students committed to academic honesty, integrity, leadership, professionalism, responsibility, and service, preparing for careers in business and economics. They are often focused on career management and global opportunities. [39]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Individuals aspiring to careers in business or economics who value a strong academic foundation, professional development, and opportunities for leadership and ethical practice should apply. Students comfortable with a traditional campus living experience will fit well. [39]

colleges.name: College of Communication & Information

majors.name: Integrated Strategic Communication

core_courses: ISC 201 Introduction to Integrated Strategic Communication
ISC 301 Strategic Writing for Integrated Strategic Communication

majors.notes: Considered a selective admission program. Median early career earnings for Public Relations, Advertising, and Applied Communication graduates are approximately $36,018. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: The CI Connect Living Learning Program (LLP) is located in Jewell Hall on North Campus, offering shared living spaces, specialized programming, and opportunities for community engagement. [3, 4]
colleges.student_archetype: First- and second-year students declared in a College of Communication and Information major, eager to 'connect' with peers, faculty, and staff, focusing on personal and career development and leadership through service-learning projects. [3]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: First- or second-year students in Communication & Information majors with a high school GPA of 2.6 or higher, who are looking for a supportive community to enhance their academic and professional growth, should apply. [3]

colleges.name: College of Design
colleges.housing_profile: Students typically reside in general university residence halls. While no specific LLP is identified, students may find communities based on broader interests or utilize facilities within their academic buildings for design-related projects. [29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Creative and innovative students with a strong visual and problem-solving aptitude, passionate about design principles and application. They often seek collaborative spaces and opportunities to showcase their work. [29, 30]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a strong portfolio and a drive for creative innovation will fit well. Undergraduate students may benefit from the general residence hall experience, fostering connections across disciplines. [29, 30]

colleges.name: College of Education
colleges.housing_profile: Students generally reside in standard university residence halls, which offer a range of room types and amenities. There is no specific LLP identified for the College of Education, but students could participate in broader interest-based LLPs. [29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Students aspiring to careers in education, teaching, and related fields, demonstrating a passion for learning, leadership, and community engagement. [29, 30]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Individuals committed to fostering learning and development in others should apply. Undergraduate students will likely find suitable housing in general residence halls, providing a diverse campus experience. [29, 30]

colleges.name: Stanley and Karen Pigman College of Engineering

majors.name: Computer Science
prerequisite_courses: ACT math score of 25 or higher (or SAT equivalent of 590 or higher) AND unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 or higher for freshman admission to Pre-Computer Science. Specific pre-major courses (Engineering Standing) with a minimum 2.5 GPA and C or better in each for full admission to the major.
weeder_courses: EGR 103 Engineering Exploration II (or EGR 215 for transfers)
PHY 242 General University Physics II Lab

core_courses: CS 215 Introduction to Program Design, Abstraction and Problem Solving

notable_professors: Dr. James Griffioen (Professor, Director of Center for Computational Sciences)
Dr. Brent Harrison (Associate Professor, Director of Undergraduate Studies in Computer Science, AI)
Dr. Hana Khamfroush (Associate Professor, Networking, Systems, Cyber Security)
Dr. Brent Seales (Stanley and Karen Pigman Heritage Science Chair, Data Science, AI, EduceLab)
Dr. Simone Silvestri (Associate Professor, Cyber-Physical-Human Systems, IoT)
Dr. Stephen Ware (Associate Professor, AI, Computational Models of Narrative)
majors.notes: Students apply as 'Pre-Computer Science' and are fully admitted after completing pre-major requirements with a minimum 2.5 GPA. Median early career earnings for Computer Engineering graduates are approximately $64,632. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
prerequisite_courses: ACT math score of 25 or higher (or SAT equivalent of 590 or higher) AND unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 or higher for freshman admission to Pre-Mechanical Engineering. Specific pre-major courses (Engineering Standing) with a minimum 2.5 GPA and C or better in each for full admission to the major.
weeder_courses: EGR 103 Engineering Exploration II (or EGR 215 for transfers)
PHY 242 General University Physics II Lab
notable_professors: Dr. Rodney Andrews (Professor, Chemical & Materials Engineering, Energy Research)
Dr. Hailong Chen (Associate Professor, Computational Mechanics & Materials)
Dr. Y. Charles Lu (Professor, Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering, Micromechanics, Nanomechanics, Finite-Element Analysis)
Dr. Suzanne Smith (Professor, Systems Engineering, Uncrewed Aircraft Systems Operations, Flexible Structures)
majors.notes: Students apply as 'Pre-Mechanical Engineering' and are fully admitted after completing pre-major requirements with a minimum 2.5 GPA. Median early career earnings for Mechanical Engineering graduates are approximately $62,556. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

majors.name: Civil Engineering
prerequisite_courses: ACT math score of 25 or higher (or SAT equivalent of 590 or higher) AND unweighted high school GPA of 3.0 or higher for freshman admission to Pre-Civil Engineering. Specific pre-major courses (Engineering Standing) with a minimum 2.5 GPA and C or better in each for full admission to the major.
weeder_courses: EGR 103 Engineering Exploration II (or EGR 215 for transfers)
PHY 242 General University Physics II Lab
notable_professors: Dr. L. Sebastian Bryson (Professor, Chair, Civil Engineering, Geotechnical Engineering)
Dr. Diana Byrne (Assistant Professor, Environmental Engineering, Water Resources)
Dr. Kelly G. Pennell (Professor, Director of UK Superfund Research Center, Environmental Engineering)
majors.notes: Students apply as 'Pre-Civil Engineering' and are fully admitted after completing pre-major requirements with a minimum 2.5 GPA. Median early career earnings for Civil Engineering graduates are approximately $55,159. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: Pigman Hall, a central campus residence hall, houses the Engineering Living Learning Program (ELLP). It offers two-bedroom, suite-style living with private bedrooms, granite countertops, carpeting, and is fully furnished. Amenities include a 24/7 staffed front desk, air-conditioning, study rooms on each floor, recreation rooms, a community kitchen, laundry facilities, and covered bike parking. It's conveniently located near the William T. Young Library, the Johnson Center, and The 90 dining facility. [19, 22, 24]
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious and goal-focused engineering or computer science students passionate about their careers, seeking academic success, career preparation, and development of technical and soft skills through a supportive, integrated community. [24, 26, 27]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a strong interest in engineering or computer science who thrive in a collaborative and academically focused residential environment should apply. A commitment to academic excellence and career development in STEM fields is highly beneficial. [24, 26, 27]

colleges.name: College of Fine Arts
colleges.housing_profile: The Creative Arts Living Learning Program is located in Holmes Hall on North Campus, near arts facilities. It provides specially designed studios for music practice (solo and ensemble), performance, art, and writing. Residents have secure daily access to these creative spaces and benefit from rooms for group interaction and collaboration. [21, 35]
colleges.student_archetype: Visual artists, dancers, performers, instrumentalists, vocalists, writers, arts administrators, photographers, and designers interested in an interdisciplinary, creative community that fosters inspiration, collaboration, and lasting friendships. All majors are welcome. [21, 35]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students passionate about creative expression, regardless of major, who thrive in a collaborative arts environment with dedicated artistic facilities and community-focused programming, should consider this LLP. [21, 35]

colleges.name: College of Health Sciences
colleges.housing_profile: Students may opt for the Interprofessional Healthcare Residential Community (IHRC) LLP in Woodland Glen V, or choose general university residence halls for undergraduates. Graduate students in health sciences can utilize graduate housing facilities. [2, 16, 29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Students dedicated to various health professions, often collaborative and community-minded, focused on patient well-being and interdisciplinary healthcare practices. [2]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a strong interest in health-related fields and a desire for an integrated learning experience should consider the IHRC LLP. Those seeking broader campus engagement can opt for general residence halls, with graduate students having apartment-style options. [2]

colleges.name: College of Nursing

majors.name: Nursing
prerequisite_courses: ANA 109 & 110 (Human Anatomy & Physiology I & II) OR ANA 209 & PGY 206 (Anatomy & Physiology I & II)
BIO 103 (Basic Biology) OR BIO 148 (General Biology I)
CHE 103 (Introductory General Chemistry) OR CHE 105 & CHE 107 (General College Chemistry I & II)
CIS 110 / WRD 110 (Composition and Communication I)
CIS 111 / WRD 111 (Composition and Communication II) OR CIS 112 (Accelerated Composition and Communication)
PSY 100 (General Psychology) OR PSY 323 (Developmental Psychology)
SOC 101 (Introductory Sociology) OR FAM 254 (Family Development) OR CPH 201 (Introduction to Public Health)
majors.special_requirements: Minimum grade of C in all prerequisite courses. State Registered Nurse Aide (SRNA) certification required before starting nursing school. Students dismissed from another nursing program or ineligible for re-admission to a prior program are not eligible for admission for five years.
notable_professors: Dr. Adebola Adegboyega (Associate Professor, Health Inequities, HPV vaccination)
Dr. Martha Biddle (Professor, Cardiovascular Health)
Dr. Ellen J. Hahn (Marcia A. Dake Professor of Nursing, Tobacco Control Research)
Dr. Mary Kay Rayens (Professor, Applied Biostatistics, Tobacco Policy, Rural Health)
Dr. Zim Okoli (Associate Professor, Nurse Researcher of the Year, Tobacco Treatment Programs, Behavioral Health)
Dr. Jessica Harman Thompson (Assistant Professor and Coordinator for the Accelerated BSN Track)
majors.notes: Selective admission. Minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 and science GPA of 3.0 required for application. All prerequisite courses must have a minimum grade of C. Median early career earnings for Registered Nursing graduates are approximately $88,300. Data source: University of Kentucky 2025-2026 academic year.

colleges.housing_profile: Nursing students primarily live in general university residence halls during their undergraduate years, transitioning to graduate housing options or off-campus living for advanced degrees. General residence halls offer various suite types with standard amenities. [29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate and dedicated students committed to patient care and health sciences. They are typically focused on their demanding curriculum and clinical experiences. [16]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students passionate about nursing and healthcare who seek a supportive academic environment and value community living during their undergraduate studies will fit well. Graduate nursing students should consider the dedicated graduate housing options. [16]

colleges.name: College of Pharmacy
colleges.housing_profile: Pharmacy students typically utilize graduate housing options such as University Flats, LTS, Shawneetown, or Greg Page. These are apartment-style accommodations, often furnished, with utilities included, designed for the needs of professional students. [12, 14, 16, 33]
colleges.student_archetype: Dedicated and detail-oriented students pursuing advanced pharmaceutical sciences, committed to innovative education and collaborative practice. They often seek a conducive environment for focused study and research. [33]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students pursuing a demanding pharmacy curriculum should consider graduate housing for its convenience and amenities that support a focused academic lifestyle. Strong organizational skills and a commitment to rigorous study are essential. [33]

colleges.name: College of Public Health
colleges.housing_profile: Students typically reside in general university residence halls for undergraduate studies or graduate housing options like University Flats, LTS, Shawneetown, or Greg Page for graduate programs. These offer a range of amenities suitable for various student needs. [12, 14, 16, 29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Students committed to addressing health issues at a community level, interested in research, policy, and public health initiatives. They often possess strong analytical and problem-solving skills. [16]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a passion for improving community health and a desire to engage in research and policy will find a strong fit. Graduate students should explore apartment-style graduate housing options for independent living. [16]

colleges.name: College of Social Work
colleges.housing_profile: Students generally live in standard university residence halls during their undergraduate years. Graduate social work students may opt for graduate housing (University Flats, LTS, Shawneetown, Greg Page) or off-campus apartments. [12, 14, 16, 29, 30]
colleges.student_archetype: Empathetic and socially conscious individuals dedicated to helping others and advocating for social justice. They are often community-oriented and committed to service. [2]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a strong commitment to social justice, community service, and helping vulnerable populations will thrive. Undergraduate students should consider general residence halls for a broader campus experience, while graduate students may prefer more independent living. [2]

colleges.name: Lewis Honors College
colleges.housing_profile: The Honors Residential Experience (HRE) is housed in Lewis and Haggin Halls on Central Campus, adjacent to the Lewis Honors College and the W.T. Young Library. Lewis Hall features double occupancy private two-bedroom suites, community kitchens, high-tech laundry facilities, wireless internet, satellite television, and various social and learning spaces including smart classrooms and a cafe. [7, 9, 10, 18]
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious, high-achieving students who prioritize their studies, holistic well-being, and community engagement. They seek interdisciplinary programs and interaction with faculty and staff. [7, 10, 23]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: High-performing students who have been admitted to the Lewis Honors College and desire an immersive living and learning experience with like-minded, academically driven peers should consider this housing. [7, 10, 23]

colleges.name: J. David Rosenberg College of Law
colleges.housing_profile: While most law students choose off-campus housing, on-campus graduate housing options are available. These include University Flats (modern, fully furnished studio and one-bedroom apartments with utilities, high-speed internet, and in-unit laundry), LTS, Shawneetown, and Greg Page, offering various one- and two-bedroom apartments. [11, 12, 13, 16, 17, 20]
colleges.student_archetype: Graduate students, including those in law, often seeking independent living near campus. They are typically focused on their demanding academic and professional programs. [8, 11, 12, 14]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Law students prioritizing convenient access to campus and seeking apartment-style living, either individually or with a family, should explore graduate housing options. Those who prefer more independence typically opt for off-campus rentals. [11, 12, 17, 20]

colleges.name: Graduate School
colleges.housing_profile: Graduate and Family Housing options include University Flats (modern, fully furnished studio and one-bedroom apartments with utilities, high-speed internet, and in-unit laundry, designed for busy lifestyles), LTS, Shawneetown, and Greg Page. These communities offer various one- and two-bedroom arrangements, some catering specifically to student families with children. [8, 12, 13, 14, 16]
colleges.student_archetype: Full-time graduate, professional, or non-traditional students, including student families, single graduate/doctoral students, visiting scholars, interns, post-doctoral fellows, and medical residents. They seek a safe, well-maintained, and accessible living environment. [8, 12, 14]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, researchers, and medical residents, or those with families, seeking furnished or unfurnished apartment-style living with included utilities and convenient campus access should apply for graduate housing. [8, 12, 13, 14, 16]

colleges.name: College of Medicine
colleges.housing_profile: Medical students, especially those in their first two years in Lexington, may utilize graduate housing options such as University Flats, LTS, Shawneetown, or Greg Page, which offer apartment-style living suitable for graduate and professional students. [12, 14, 25]
colleges.student_archetype: Highly dedicated and focused students pursuing rigorous medical training, often seeking convenient and mature living environments. They may also be involved in clinical service and research. [12, 14, 25]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Prospective medical students should focus on securing graduate housing or off-campus apartments that provide a quiet and conducive environment for intensive study. Those looking for convenience to the medical campus will find graduate housing beneficial. [12, 14, 25]

colleges.name: College of Dentistry
colleges.housing_profile: Similar to other professional programs, students in the College of Dentistry would likely utilize graduate housing options such as University Flats, LTS, Shawneetown, or Greg Page, which offer apartment-style living. [8, 12, 14, 16]
colleges.student_archetype: Highly motivated and dedicated individuals pursuing a demanding professional degree in dentistry, focused on clinical skills and patient care. [8, 12, 14, 16]
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Prospective dental students should explore graduate housing options for convenient, mature living that supports rigorous academic and clinical schedules. Strong commitment to the dental profession is essential. [8, 12, 14, 16]

minors_certificates: Writing, Rhetoric and Digital Studies Minor

application_deadlines.notes: Encouraged for consideration for Lewis Honors College, competitive and academic scholarships, or if planning to live on campus. This deadline has passed for Fall 2026 admission.
Applying after December 1 may exclude consideration for Lewis Honors College or competitive and academic scholarships.

supplemental_requirements.details: Multiple secondary essays are required. Prompts for 2025-2026 include: 'Why have you chosen to apply to the University of Kentucky College of Medicine?' (1,500 characters max); 'Please describe how your past experiences or future plans contribute to enriching and enhancing the learning environment at UKCOM.' (1,500 characters); 'If you are a non Kentucky resident, you are required to elaborate on your Kentucky ties if applicable (personal, familial e.g.)' (700 characters max); 'Your combination of life experiences make you uniquely you. Talk about one such experience and how it has helped you prepare to be a physician.'; 'Describe an experience or situation which made you feel grateful?'; 'Please share unique, personally important, and/or challenging facts in your background... Please discuss how such factors have influenced your goals and preparation for a career in medicine.'; 'Describe a situation where you were not in the majority.'; 'Please elaborate on your selection of first-choice campus.'; and 'Please elaborate on your selection of alternate campus (if applicable).' (Additional prompts may also be present related to using unscheduled time for learning, physician competencies, community service, emotional distance in patient care, and engaged learning experiences).

supplemental_requirements.target_program: J. David Rosenberg College of Law
supplemental_requirements.details: A personal statement (2-3 pages, double-spaced) is required. Optional supplemental essays (one page each) can be submitted on topics such as interest in the College of Law, specific interest in a specialty/practice area, or describing an obstacle overcome.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: January 23 and 24, 2026; February 13 and 14, 2026; February 20 and 21, 2026
supplemental_requirements.details: An audition is required for prospective majors. Graduate students are encouraged to audition in January for fellowship eligibility.
A successful audition is required to be declared a dance major. Auditions include ballet, modern, jazz, improvisation, and interviews. Remote video auditions are also accepted.

supplemental_requirements.deadline: October 5 (Fall for current students); January 25 (Spring for current and incoming students)
supplemental_requirements.details: A successful audition is required. Video submissions include 2 contrasting songs (32 bars/1-1:30 minutes each) and a 1-minute monologue.

A Statement of Intent (300 words maximum) explaining the rationale for applying and how prior experience prepares for success, and an Admission Essay (500 words maximum) addressing the prompt: 'Kentucky is one of four states that is a Commonwealth. The term means the state is for the common good. What do you consider to be for the common good and how do you hope to use your life experiences, challenges, uniqueness, and intellect to contribute to the common good in your community, as you define it?' are required.

A Statement of Purpose is listed as a supporting document for undergraduate admissions, particularly for international applicants or those using the Common App. While not explicitly detailed as a 'supplemental essay' with a specific prompt for all applicants, it serves a similar function in allowing applicants to present their goals and qualifications.

holistic_factors.specific_differentiators: The University of Kentucky employs a holistic review process, particularly for test-optional applicants and for admission to programs like the Lewis Honors College. This review considers the rigor of high school coursework, activities and engagement outside the classroom, and a written essay. The Lewis Honors College specifically values academic preparation, the strength of the application essay, leadership and involvement, and notable awards and achievements. While not a direct admissions boost, there are extensive 'First-Generation Programs' offering tailored initiatives, academic support, scholarships, and a Living Learning Community to empower first-generation students. Additionally, a 'Legacy Tuition Program' offers partial tuition awards to eligible non-resident children of UK graduates who are life members of the UK Alumni Association.

essay_prompts.Prompt: Kentucky is one of four states that is a Commonwealth. The term means the state is for the common good. What do you consider to be for the common good and how do you hope to use your life experiences, challenges, uniqueness, and intellect to contribute to the common good in your community, as you define it?
essay_prompts.Type: Community, Personal, Why This School (through the lens of its "Commonwealth" identity)
essay_prompts.Required/Optional: Required for application to the Lewis Honors College
Brainstorming Questions: What specific local, national, or global issues do you believe need to be addressed for the betterment of society, and why do you feel strongly about them?
Reflect on a time when you personally contributed to a group or community. What was your role, what challenges did you face, and what was the outcome?
Considering your unique skills, talents, or perspectives, how could these be applied to solve a problem or improve a situation within a community you care about?
Think about a personal challenge or a unique experience you've had. How has it shaped your understanding of what "the common good" means, and how might it inform your future contributions?
Beyond academic achievements, what aspects of your intellect or character do you believe would be most valuable in collaborating with others to work towards a shared benefit?

major_selection_tactics: Apply to less competitive majors if not set on highly selective programs like certain engineering fields, nursing, or the Gatton College of Business and Economics, as most undergraduate majors at UK permit direct admission.

Consider applying as 'undeclared' within a broader college, especially if uncertain about a specific competitive major, as you may be placed into an alternate major if your initial selective choice is not granted.

Research major-specific admission requirements, particularly for programs in the Gatton College of Business and Economics or accelerated programs like UK BLUE, which has higher GPA, test score recommendations, and often require separate applications or essays beyond general university admission.

Be aware that highly popular majors such as Nursing, Biology, and various Business and Engineering fields, while not always explicitly labeled as 'selective' in the same way as some programs, may have more competition for enrollment or progression to upper-division status.
college_ranking_tactics: Focus on colleges with strong national or regional reputations in specific academic programs of interest (e.g., agriculture, business, engineering, nursing, pharmacy).
Investigate colleges and programs that offer significant undergraduate research opportunities and access to faculty expertise.
Consider the quality and availability of specialized campus facilities, labs, and technology directly relevant to the desired field of study within each college.
Look into the specific student support, advising, and career development resources offered by individual colleges at the University of Kentucky.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: When applying to competitive or 'selective' majors at the University of Kentucky, applicants may be placed into an alternate major if not initially admitted to their first choice. The application typically allows for selecting both a first and second choice major. Therefore, strategically listing a less selective major or one in a different college can serve as an alternate or backup plan.

financials.notes: The University of Kentucky has made efforts to reallocate its financial aid, moving to prioritize need-based aid over purely merit-based aid to better support students with unmet financial needs.

scholarships.name: Presidential Scholarship
scholarships.eligibility: Traditionally, applicants should have at least a 3.5 GPA and an ACT test score of 31 or SAT test score of 1390. However, the University of Kentucky also heavily weighs unweighted high school GPA and evaluates students for scholarship awarding through extensive data assessment beyond test scores. All eligible students who apply by the Early Action deadline (December 1st) are considered, regardless of submitting test scores.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration upon completion of the admission application and all supporting documents by the December 1st Early Action deadline.

scholarships.name: Singletary Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Full tuition + $10,000/year housing stipend for the first two years (if living on campus).
scholarships.eligibility: Highly competitive, implied for top academic performers. Historically, recipients have had exceptional academic records (e.g., 4.4 weighted GPA and 34 ACT).
scholarships.application_method: Automatic consideration for top applicants who complete the admission application and supporting documents by the Early Action deadline.

scholarships.name: William C. Parker Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Varies (awarded with the goal of supporting student success).
scholarships.eligibility: Incoming first-time freshmen with a minimum unweighted high school GPA of 2.50. Awarded based on a holistic review of the student's application for admission.
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration; no additional steps are required. For maximum consideration, apply by the Early Action deadline of December 1st.

scholarships.name: College of Engineering Incoming Freshman Merit-Based Scholarship Program
scholarships.amount: $2,000 per year, renewable for four years (up to $8,000 total). This scholarship can stack on top of other university awards up to the total cost of attendance.
scholarships.eligibility: Students must apply to UK and select a College of Engineering major by December 1, have a composite score of 30 on the ACT or 1360 on the SAT (with a math score of 33 on the ACT or 740 on the SAT), and a 3.50 unweighted high school GPA.
scholarships.application_method: No separate application; candidates' admission application and supporting materials are reviewed. Selected recipients are notified in February.

scholarships.name: Need-Based Scholarships (General)
scholarships.eligibility: Students must be admitted to the university and complete the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA).
scholarships.application_method: Complete the FAFSA. Offers are typically announced in late spring each year.

ap_policy.general_rule: The University of Kentucky generally awards credit for AP exam scores of 3, 4, or 5. Many introductory courses grant credit for a score of 3, while others require a 4 or 5 for specific courses or higher-level credit. Detailed equivalencies are provided on their official AP credit equivalency page.

ib_policy.general_rule: The University of Kentucky awards credit for International Baccalaureate (IB) Higher Level (HL) exam scores of 5, 6, or 7. Credit is also awarded for several Standard Level (SL) exams with scores of 5, 6, or 7. Specific course equivalencies are provided on their official IB credit equivalency page.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: The University of Kentucky offers a comprehensive online transfer equivalency database that allows prospective students to determine how courses from other regionally accredited institutions will transfer. They provide clear guidance and support for transfer students, indicating a structured and transparent process for evaluating and applying transfer credits.

what_it_takes: Proactive engagement in campus life and academic opportunities.
Strong time management skills to balance coursework and social activities.
Willingness to seek out and utilize campus resources like advising, tutoring, and career services.
Networking with professors, TAs, and peers to build a supportive community.
Balancing academic rigor with the vibrant social scene and extracurriculars.
common_activities: Attending University of Kentucky basketball and football games (Big Blue Nation!), especially at Rupp Arena.
Participating in Greek life (fraternities and sororities) which have a significant presence.
Joining various student organizations, clubs, and academic societies based on interests.
Studying and collaborating in libraries like the William T. Young Library.
Exploring downtown Lexington, local restaurants, and events near campus.
essay_tips: Highlight your passion for specific academic programs or research opportunities unique to UK.
Showcase any connection you have to Kentucky's culture, values, or the region.
Emphasize leadership roles, community involvement, and how you've made an impact.
Demonstrate how you plan to contribute to the UK community, beyond just academics.
Be authentic and tell a personal story that reveals your character and aspirations.
red_flags: Overcommitting to too many social activities at the expense of academic responsibilities.
Neglecting to utilize the numerous academic and personal support services available on campus.
Failing to engage with professors and TAs, especially in larger introductory courses.
Procrastinating on assignments and not keeping up with a demanding course load.
Getting 'lost in the crowd' of a large university by not actively seeking connections.
insights: UK fosters a strong sense of community and pride, especially around its athletic programs.
There are countless opportunities for involvement; students need to be proactive in finding them.
Lexington offers a fantastic college town experience with a variety of dining, entertainment, and cultural options.
The campus is extensive and beautiful, so be prepared for walking or utilizing campus shuttles.
While known for its lively social scene, the academic programs are rigorous and require dedication.

outcomes.notes: 10 years after enrolling, the average income of former University of Kentucky students who are working and no longer in school is $51,000, which is 49% higher than the national median.
